homepage.title: INPLUGS-CO₂
homepage.subtitle: The Interactive Platform for Understanding Geological Storage of CO₂ helps you understand how this technology works.

box1.title: CO₂ capture
box1.description: CO₂ is <term-tooltip term="captured">captured</term-tooltip> directly from large emitters before being released in the atmosphere

box2.title: CO₂ compression & injection
box2.description: <term-tooltip term="captured">Captured</term-tooltip> CO₂ is compressed to <term-tooltip term="liquid">liquid</term-tooltip> or <term-tooltip term="supercritical">supercritical</term-tooltip> form and injected in the subsurface at min. depth 700-800m

box3.title: CO₂ storage
box3.description: CO₂ is injected in a <term-tooltip term="porous">porous</term-tooltip> geological layer that is called <term-tooltip term="reservoir">reservoir</term-tooltip>

box4.title: CO₂ migration
box4.description: The injected CO₂ is <term-tooltip term="less dense">less dense</term-tooltip> than the existing water in the pores of the reservoir, and starts migrating upwards

box5.title: CO₂ trapping
box5.description: The <term-tooltip term="buoyant">buoyant</term-tooltip> CO₂ is stopped from escaping to the surface thanks to the existence of the <term-tooltip term="caprock">caprock</term-tooltip>, a geological layer above the reservoir, that acts as a <term-tooltip term="hydromechanical barrier">hydromechanical barrier</term-tooltip>

why.title: Why Geological Carbon Storage ?
why.text_1: CO₂ is a major greenhouse gas. Geological storage helps reduce emissions from heavy industries (e.g., steel, cement, power plants) that are difficult to decarbonize.
why.text_2: Most climate models show we can’t reach net-zero emissions without some form of carbon capture and storage, especially for hard-to-abate sectors.
why.text_3: Deep geological formations (like depleted oil and gas fields or deep saline aquifers) can trap CO₂ for thousands to millions of years.

world.title:
GCS
in the World
world.text_1: In 2025?, 53 CCS projects are in operation, enabling the storage of approximately 55 MtCO₂ per year, or an average of 1.5 MtCO₂ per project. Considering the carbon neutrality targets for 2040, approximately 2,500 additional projects would be needed worldwide to capture the estimated 40 gigatons of CO₂ per year required by that date. (Sources: IEA and AAGP)

swiss.title: Geological Carbon Storage in Switzerland
swiss.text_1: Switzerland is actively exploring geological carbon storage as part of its climate strategy, with several initiatives and studies underway.

initiative_1.name: Swiss CCS Research
initiative_1.description: Swiss research institutions are conducting studies on the feasibility of CO₂ storage in deep saline aquifers and depleted oil and gas fields.

initiative_2.name: Pilot Projects
initiative_2.description: Pilot projects are being developed to test CO₂ capture and storage technologies in various industrial sectors.

initiative_3.name: Regulatory Framework
initiative_3.description: Switzerland is working on establishing a regulatory framework to ensure the safe and effective implementation of geological carbon storage.

q1.question: Is geological carbon storage safe?
q1.answer: Yes, when properly managed, geological carbon storage is considered safe. It involves injecting CO₂ into deep underground rock formations that are well understood and monitored to prevent leaks.

q2.question: How does GCS work?
q2.answer: GCS works by capturing CO2 at its source, compressing it, transporting it to a storage site, and injecting it into deep underground rock formations where it is permanently stored.

q3.question: Is GCS safe?
q3.answer: Yes, GCS is considered safe when properly implemented. The technology has been used for decades, and extensive monitoring ensures the stored CO2 remains secure.

intro.title: About
intro.subtitle:
INPLUGS-CO2 aims to contribute to raising awareness on the topic of geological CO2 storage, its risks and urgency.
It targets two main groups:

general.title: General public
general.text: Those wishing to understand how GCS works, why the technology is interesting and potentially needed to reduce carbon emissions, and what are the risks and their mitigation.

academic.title: Scientists/engineers
academic.text: Experts from academia and industry who are looking for high quality open source data on GCS. This part of the website (starting early 2026) is designed around a novel metre-scale testbed in EPFL and can serve as a database for other GCS projects at pilot and demonstration scales.

intro.subtitle_2: Main principles, key findings and live results will be actively shared with the broader public in order to promote safe implementation of CO2 storage at larger scales.

missions.title: Mission & Valeurs
missions.text: INPLUGS-CO2 is an independent initiative launched by researchers at EPFL that aims to share impartial information on geological CO2 storage technology. Due to human-induced climate change, reducing carbon emissions is becoming an increasingly urgent issue, and CCS technologies (including GCS) can have a significant impact in this regard. Our efforts aim to provide a solid foundation on how GCS works so that readers can form an objective opinion on the subject. In other words, INPLUGS-CO2's mission is not to promote GCS, but to inform the public about it using facts and data, in the hope that this will help society to be more aware and develop a critical mind in the face of the intense flow of often unverified information to which it is exposed.
